In terms of speed, the New York Minute seems to have been eclipsed by Internet Time. Compared with the almost instant gratification of e-mail, waiting for an overnight courier to deliver a package can feel like waiting for a glacier to move.
NextJet, a new company based in Dallas, is aiming to fill the needs of people who need materials delivered the same day, no matter where they live in the United States.

In creating a system that can get a package from Point A to Point B by the fastest means possible, NextJet has developed a custom database that combines the schedules of 30,000 commercial airline flights, along with the availability of 300 ground couriers.

To use the service, a customer can either call (888) 639-8538 or visit the company's Web site at www.nextjet.com. On the Web site, the customer can enter the recipient's and the sender's ZIP codes in a form on the page and quickly get several price quotations and estimated delivery times for door-to-door service.

To send a 10-pound package from Manhattan to Beverly Hills on a Wednesday afternoon, for example, costs about $200. The package would leave New York around 1:30 p.m. Eastern time and arrive in California about 7:10 p.m. Pacific time. Customers can track their shipments on the NextJet Web site.
To those who desperately need shipments as soon as possible, the slightly higher cost may be well worth it, in terms of both productivity and antacid tablets.
